welcome:
Welcome to the user study on AI-assisted decision making!

Please, make sure you are accessing this on a desktop or laptop.
We cannot guarantee correct display of the study on phones and tablets.

At the top of the screen you will find a progress bar, telling you how far you are in the study.
Do not try to refresh this window at any point as this will restart the study and any of your progress will be lost!

This window will switch to full screen mode when you press the button below.
Please do not exit full screen during the study.

Imprint | Data Protection
consent:
Information and consent form

 

User Study on Human-Aligned Calibration for AI-Assisted Decision Making




Contact project team:                            Nina Corvelo Benz, ETH Zurich/MPI-SWS, ninacobe@mpi-sws.org

Data Protection Officer ETH Zurich:      Tomislav Mitar (tomislav.mitar@sl.ethz.ch)

 

We would like to ask you if you are willing to participate in our research project. Your participation is voluntary. Please read the text below carefully and ask the conducting person about anything you do not understand or would like to know.

 

 

What is investigated and how?

This user study is being conducted by Nina Laura Corvelo Benz and Manuel Gomez-Rodriguez at ETH Zurich and the Max Planck Institute for Software Systems. The purpose of this study is to compare how participants perform decision making with and without AI-assistance. For this purpose, we have designed a game of cards where players make decisions before and after observing advice from an AI. We hope that, in the future, people might benefit from this study through improved understanding of the effect of AI-assistance in human decision making.

 

Who can participate?

Any US based Prolific worker can participate in this study if they have a high approval rate, are proficient in English and have completed a high school diploma or higher level of education.

 

What am I supposed to do as a participant?

As a participant in this study, you will play a game of cards. In each round of this game, you will see part of a pile of red and black cards for a short amount of time. A random card will be drawn from the entire pile and, based on what you saw, we will ask you how confident you are that the color of this card is red.

We will then ask you to guess the color of this card before and after showing you how confident the AI is that the color is red. By correctly guessing the color of the card, you collect points. Your goal is to collect as many points as possible. After each round and when you complete the game, we will ask you four questions about your thoughts on the AI. In the end, there will be also a short demographic survey asking for your age, gender, highest acquired degree and the subject of this degree (you have the option to not disclose any of this information).

 

What are my rights during participation? 

Your participation in this study is voluntary. You may withdraw your participation at any time during the study by leaving this website (e.g., closing your browser window). In that case, none of your data will be stored and, hence, you will not be compensated.

 

What risks and benefits can I expect?

Risks involved in this study are the same as those normally associated with using a computer (e.g. mild eye/arm strain). There are no direct benefits from participating in this study.

 

Will I be compensated for participating?

After finishing the study, you will be redirected to Prolific and you will be compensated for your participation following your agreement with Prolific. We will also pay out a bonus compensation according to your performance in the game through Prolific. You will be responsible for any taxes assessed on the compensation.

 

What data is collected from me and how is it used?

In this user study, your behavioral data in the game as well as some demographic information will be collected. Both behavioral data and demographic information will be stored and published in anonymized form, thus, no conclusions can be drawn about individuals. This anonymized data and the results of the study will be publicly available on GitHub to encourage future research on AI-assisted decision making. No personal data about you will be collected except for your Prolific ID, which we need to compensate you. Your Profilic ID will be stored separately and will be deleted as soon as compensation is completed. Members of the ETH Zurich Ethics Commission may access the original data for examination purposes. Strict confidentiality will be observed at any time.

 

What are my rights to my personal data?

Before the irrevocable anonymization or deletion of the collected data, you can request information about the personal data collected from you at any time and without giving reasons. You can also request that it be rectified, handed over to you, barred for processing or erased. To do so, please contact the person indicated above.

 

Who funds this study?

The Max-Planck Institute for Software Systems funds this study.

 

How am I insured?

Adverse health effects that are directly caused by the study and can be demonstrated to be attributable to fault on the part of the project team or ETH Zurich are covered by ETH's liability insurance. You are responsible for insuring yourself against any other adverse health effects such as might occur.

 

Who reviewed this study?

This study was examined by the ETH Zurich Ethics Commission as proposal EK-2024-N-49.

 

Complaints office

The secretariat of the ETH Zurich Ethics Committee is available to help you with complaints in connection with your participation. Contact: ethics@sl.ethz.ch or 0041 44 632 85 72.

 

 

Consent Form

 

By clicking the button below, I, the participant, confirm that:

-        I have read and understood the study information. My questions have been answered completely and to my satisfaction.

-        I comply with the inclusion and exclusion criteria for participation described above. I am aware of the requirements and restrictions to be observed during the study.

-        I have had enough time to decide about my participation.

-        I participate in this study voluntarily and consent that my personal data be used as described above.

-        I understand that I can stop participating at any moment.

Imprint | Data Protection
instructions:
Game Instructions

In this study, you will play a game of cards.
In each round, a random game pile of cards is chosen and you will see only part of this game pile for a short amount of time.
The amount of red and black cards in the game pile is not necessarily the same
and the placement of the cards in the screen is not necessarily at random.

Game Instructions

The cards of the game pile not shown will appear flipped.

Game Instructions

We will pick one random card out of the entire game pile.
Based on the part of the game pile you saw,
we will first ask you what your confidence is that this card is red on a scale of 0% to 100%.

Game Instructions

Based on your stated confidence, we will ask you to make an initial guess on the color of the picked card.

Game Instructions

After your initial guess, we will provide you with an AI that will assist you in making your final guess!

The AI sees the entire game pile and estimates how likely it is that the picked card is red.
Note that this estimate may have some unknown error, and thus may not be fully accurate.
We will then ask if your initial confidence has changed.

Game Instructions

Based on your stated confidence, you will be asked to make your final guess on the color of the picked card.

Game Instructions

You win 1 point in a round if your final guess matches the color of the picked card.
You lose 1 point if your final guess does not match the color of the picked card.
Your initial guess does not award nor deduct you any points. However, we ask you to give the best possible initial guess.

Game Instructions

After each round, we will ask you two questions about your thoughts on the AI.
These questions regard your perception of the AI's accuracy and how the AI affected how many points you won.

Next, you will run through an example of a round in the game.
Points are not counted yet.

game_play.human_conf:
A random card will be picked from this round’s game pile.
State your confidence that the picked card is red:

(Here, you need to click a value on the scale to click next.)
game_play.decision: what is your initial guess for the color of the picked card?

game_play_AI.AI_conf: The AI’s estimated likelihood that the picked card is red:
game_play_AI.human_AI_conf: What is your confidence that the picked card is red after seeing the AI's estimate:
game_play_AI.decision: what is your final guess for the color of the picked card?

survey.prompt: I think the AI's estimate was accurate in this round.
survey.name: accuracy

survey: I won points in this round because I changed my guess based on the AI's estimate.
I lost points in this round because I changed my guess based on the AI's estimate.
The AI's estimate did not change my guess in this round.

final_survey.prompt: Overall, I think the AI's estimates were accurate.
final_survey.name: accuracy

final_survey.prompt: Overall, the AI's estimates affected my confidence.
final_survey.name: changed_confidence

final_survey.prompt: Overall, I trust the estimates of the AI.
final_survey.name: trust

final_survey: Overall, the AI's estimates changed my guess for the better, and I would have gained less points without the AI.
Overall, the AI's estimates changed my guess for the worse, and I would have gained more points without the AI.
Overall, the AI's estimates did not change my guess, and I would have gained a similar amount of points without the AI.
Overall, the AI's estimates did not change my guess, and I believe I would have gained less points by trusting the AI.
Overall, the AI's estimates did not change my guess, but I believe I would have gained more points by trusting the AI.
